properties.title: Apache James Server 3 - Recipient Rewrite Table Configuration

section.name: Recipient Rewrite Table Configuration
section.p: Consult recipientrewritetable.xml in GIT to get some examples and hints.

subsection.name: JPA Recipient Rewrite Table
subsection.p: The default table for storing James' Recipient Rewrite mappings.
Using Spring, you should add a class attribute to recipientrewritetable tag (class="org.apache.james.rrt.jpa.JPARecipientRewriteTable). It has no effect with Guice wiring.

dl.dd: If set recursiveMapping false only the first mapping will get processed - Default true.
By setting the mappingLimit you can specify how much mapping will get processed before a bounce will send. This avoid infinity loops. Default 10.

subsection.name: XML Recipient Rewrite Table
subsection.p: Add a class attribute to recipientrewritetable tag (class="org.apache.james.rrt.xml.XMLRecipientRewriteTable).

dl.dd: If set recursiveMapping false only the first mapping will get processed - Default true.
By setting the mappingLimit you can specify how much mapping will get processed before a bounce will send. This avoid infinity loops. Default 10.

subsection.name: JDBC Recipient Rewrite Table
subsection.p: Add a class attribute and a destinationURL attributed to recipientrewritetable tag (class="org.apache.james.rrt.jdbc.JDBCRecipientRewriteTable" destinationURL="db://maildb/RecipientRewriteTable").
Use these configurations to store the RecipientRewriteTable in a database.

dl.dd: If set recursiveMapping false only the first mapping will get processed - Default true.
By setting the mappingLimit you can specify how much mapping will get processed before a bounce will send. This avoid infinity loops. Default 10.
